{{primary sources|date=May 2020}} {{Infobox museum | name = Cosmic Dawn Center (DAWN) | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | image = Logo_for_DAWN_with_blue_horizon.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | alt = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_dot_label = | coordinates = | former_name = | established = 2017 | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = Lyngbyvej 2, 2100 [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] and Elektrovej 327, 2800 [[Kgs. Lyngby]], [[Denmark]] | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = [[Sune Toft]] with co-director [[Thomas Greve]] | president = | chairperson = | curator = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = [https://dawn.nbi.ku.dk/ DAWN Homepage] | embedded = }} The '''Cosmic Dawn Center''' is an [[Astronomy]]/[[Cosmology]] research center, founded as a collaboration between the [[Niels Bohr Institute]] of the [[University of Copenhagen]] and [[DTU Space]] of the [[Danish Technical University]] (DTU). The center is led by center director and NBI Professor [[Sune Toft]] and center co-director [[Thomas Greve]], Professor at DTU and [[University College London|UCL]].<ref name=greve>{{citation|url=https://www.ucl.ac.uk/astrophysics/people/thomas-greve|title=Thomas Greve profile at UCL|work=[[University College London]]|date=15 April 2020}}</ref> The main objective of the center is to investigate the period known as the [[Cosmic Dawn]] (the transition period following the [[Cosmic Dark Ages]]<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.space.com/41550-breaking-of-the-cosmic-dawn.htmll|title=Space.com article on the Cosmic Dawn and the formation of the first stars|date=15 April 2020}}</ref>), i.e. the [[reionization]] of the Universe and the formation of the first galaxies, through observations as well as through theory and simulations.<ref>{{citation|url=https://dawn.nbi.ku.dk/about-dawn/|title=Mission Statement|work=Cosmic Dawn Center|date=25 February 2020}}</ref><ref name=dginauguration>{{citation|url=https://dg.dk/en/inauguration-of-dawn-the-cosmic-dawn-center/|title=DNRF article on the inauguration of DAWN|work=[[Danish National Research Foundation]]|date=14 March 2020}}</ref><ref name=natureindex>{{citation|url=https://www.natureindex.com/institution-outputs/denmark/cosmic-dawn-center-dawn/5a8656606f5bfb4d6110d93e|title=The Cosmic Dawn Center profile on Nature|work=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|date=14 March 2020}}</ref> The Cosmic Dawn Center also runs two summer programs for mainly U.S. undergraduates, the DAWN-IRES program, funded by [[National Science Foundation]],<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.dawnires.com/|title=DAWN-IRES website|date=14 March 2020}}</ref> and a SURF (Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship).<ref>{{citation|url=https://sfp.caltech.edu/programs/surf|title=Caltech SURF program|date=14 March 2020}}</ref> program for [[California Institute of Technology]] students<ref>{{citation|url=http://announcements.surf.caltech.edu/index.cfm?event=ViewAODetail&id=2218&inFrame=&type=SURF&formType=AO_CIT|title=Caltech SURF Announcement of Opportunity|date=14 March 2020}}</ref>
== Research ==
Research conducted at the center is focused on the specific period in the history of the Universe known as the [[Cosmic Dawn]]. This largely unexplored period, 300-600 million years after the [[Big Bang]] is when the first stars, black holes and galaxies are believed to have formed.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.space.com/39837-first-stars-universe-fingerprints-dark-matter.html|title=Cosmic Dawn: Astronomers Find Fingerprints of Universe's First Stars|author=Wall, Mike|date=28 February 2018|website=Space.com|accessdate=15 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://science.time.com/2012/12/14/cosmic-dawn-hubble-spots-some-granddaddy-galaxies/|work =[[Time Magazine]]|title=Cosmic Dawn: How the Universe's Lights Went On|author=Lemonick, Michael D.|date=14 December 2012 |accessdate=15 April 2020}}</ref> Many of the observations used by the center originate from the [[Atacama Large Millimeter Array]] (ALMA), one of the more powerful telescopes in the world.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.almaobservatory.org/en/home/|title=ALMA homepage|date=15 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/cosmic-dawn/|work=[[National Geographic]]|title=Cosmic Dawn|author=Bhattacharjee, Yudhijit |date=9 March 2019|accessdate=15 April 2020}}</ref> In the future, the center aims to mainly use the [[James Webb Space Telescope]]<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/jwst/results/|title=ESA JWST Workshops|date=15 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2019/nasa-s-webb-to-explore-galaxies-from-cosmic-dawn-to-present-day|title=NASA JWST will explore the Cosmic Dawn|date=15 April 2020}}</ref> (planned to start operating in 2021<ref name=bridenstine-launch>{{cite tweet |author-link=Jim Bridenstine |user=JimBridenstine |number=1012008010150006786 |title=The James Webb Space Telescope will produce first of its kind, world-class science. Based on recommendations by an Independent Review Board, the new launch date for @NASAWebb is March 30, 2021. I'm looking forward to the launch of this historic mission. |date=27 June 2018 |access-date=27 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="NASAJWSTdelay2021">{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=NASA Completes Webb Telescope Review, Commits to Launch in Early 2021|url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-completes-webb-telescope-review-commits-to-launch-in-early-2021|accessdate=27 June 2018|publisher=NASA|date=27 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="WP-20180724">{{cite news |last1=Kaplan |first1=Sarah |last2=Achenbach |first2=Joel |title=NASA's next great space telescope is stuck on Earth after screwy errors |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/nasas-next-great-space-telescope-is-stuck-on-earth-after-screwy-errors/2018/07/24/742f17d4-8e93-11e8-8322-b5482bf5e0f5_story.html |date=24 July 2018 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=25 July 2018 }}</ref> Work on the telescope was suspended in March 2020 due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://spacenews.com/coronavirus-pauses-work-on-jwst/|title=Coronavirus pauses work on JWST|date=March 20, 2020|first=Jeff| last=Foust|authorlink=Jeff Foust|publisher=[[SpaceNews]]}}</ref>), the [[Euclid (spacecraft)|Euclid Telescope]] of the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA) (planned to start operating in 2022<ref name="Arianespace">{{cite web|url=http://www.esa.int/Science_Exploration/Space_Science/Arianespace_and_ESA_announce_the_Euclid_satellite_s_launch_contract_for_dark_energy_exploration|title=Arianespace and ESA announce the Euclid satellite's launch contract for dark energy exploration|website=esa.int|date=7 January 2020}}</ref>), but is also involved with many other missions.
=== Major publications and collaborations ===
Accurate as of 2020-04-17. Taken as the highest impact papers with participation of at least one DAWN affiliate.<ref name=natureindex />
=== Major papers ===
*Observation of inverse Compton emission from a long γ-ray burst:<ref>{{cite journal |author=Acciari, V.A.; Ansoldi, S.; Antonelli, L.A.|display-authors=etal |title=Observation of inverse Compton emission from a long γ-ray burst |journal=Nature |date=November 2019 |volume=575 |issue=7783 |pages=459–463 |doi=10.1038/s41586-019-1754-6 |pmid=31748725 |bibcode=2019Natur.575..459M |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1754-6 |issn=1476-4687}}</ref> *Identification of strontium in the merger of two neutron stars:<ref>{{cite journal |author=Watson, D.; Hansen, C.J.; Selsing, J.|display-authors=etal|title=Identification of strontium in the merger of two neutron stars |journal=Nature |date=October 2019 |volume=574 |issue=7779 |pages=497–500 |doi=10.1038/s41586-019-1676-3 |pmid=31645733|arxiv=1910.10510|bibcode=2019Natur.574..497W|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1676-3 |language=en |issn=1476-4687}}</ref> *Signatures of a jet cocoon in early spectra of a supernova associated with a γ-ray burst:<ref>{{cite journal |author=Izzo, L.; de Ugarte Postigo, A.; Maeda, K.|display-authors=etal|title=Signatures of a jet cocoon in early spectra of a supernova associated with a γ-ray burst |journal=Nature |date=January 2019 |volume=565 |issue=7739 |pages=324–327 |doi=10.1038/s41586-018-0826-3 |pmid=30651614|arxiv=1901.05500|bibcode=2019Natur.565..324I|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-018-0826-3 |language=en |issn=1476-4687}}</ref> *Stellar Velocity Dispersion of a Massive Quenching Galaxy at z = 4.01:<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Tanaka, Masayuki |author2=Valentino, Francesco |author3=Toft, Sune |display-authors=etal|title=Stellar Velocity Dispersion of a Massive Quenching Galaxy at z = 4.01 |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |date=6 November 2019 |volume=885 |issue=2 |pages=L34 |doi=10.3847/2041-8213/ab4ff3 |arxiv=1909.10721|bibcode=2019ApJ...885L..34T|issn=2041-8213}}</ref>
As per 18 April 2020, DAWN authors have published at least 187 refereed papers garnering 1602 citations, which, among others, can be found at the NASA/ADS library.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/search/p_=0&q=aff%3A%22cosmic%20dawn%20center%22&sort=date%20desc%2C%20bibcode%20desc|title=ADS paper search with aff:"cosmic dawn center"|access-date= 18 April 2020}}</ref> A paper library including all papers written by DAWN members since the official inauguration can be found [https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/user/libraries/n7YvxRasSCGO3rGoc_GrIQ here].
=== Collaborations ===
* [[James Webb Space Telescope]]: DAWN scientists have partaken in the construction of three instruments (NIRSpec, MIRI and NIRISS),<ref>{{citation|url=https://jwst.nasa.gov/index.html|title=James Webb Space Telescope|accessdate=15 April 2020}}</ref> and will be involved in the analysis of the first data from the telescope.<ref name="dawn-research">{{cite web |title=Cosmic Dawn Center - Research at DAWN |url=https://dawn.nbi.ku.dk/research/ |website=dawn.nbi.ku.dk |accessdate=3 May 2020 |language=en |date=19 July 2017}}</ref> * [[Atacama Large Millimeter Array|Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA)]]<ref name="dawn-research" /> *[http://sci.esa.int/euclid/ Euclid]<ref name="dawn-research" /> *[[Cosmic Evolution Survey]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://cosmos.astro.caltech.edu/page/members|title=COSMOS Members|date=15 April 2020}}</ref> *[http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/HST-Survey/ Hubble Frontier Field] *[https://buffalo.ipac.caltech.edu/ Buffalo] Led by DAWN PI [[Charles Steinhardt]]<ref>{{citation|url=https://buffalo.ipac.caltech.edu/|title=Buffalo Survey|date=14 March 2020}}</ref> *[https://3dhst.research.yale.edu/Home.html/ 3DHST] *[https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/SMUVS/overview.html SMUVS] *[http://ultravista.org/ Ultravista] *[http://splash-survey.org/ Splash]
=== Other ===
A short summary of research conducted by the 2019 SURF students at The Cosmic Dawn Center can be found on the Caltech Student-Faculty program website.<ref>{{citation|url=http://sfp.caltech.edu/documents/7373/__Fall_Abstract_Book_-_Combined_for_Printing.pdf|title=Caltech SURF Abstract Book 2019|date=15 April 2020}}</ref>
== Funding ==
The Cosmic Dawn Center is a DNRF Center of Excellence.<ref name=dginauguration />
== Senior academic staff == <small>As of 15 April 2020</small><ref>{{citation|url=https://dawn.nbi.ku.dk/staff/staff-and-students/|title=Staff and Student profiles|work=Cosmic Dawn Center|date=15 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nbi.ku.dk/ansatte/|title=Staff of the Niels Bohr Institute|work=[[Niels Bohr Institute]]|date=14 March 2020}}</ref>
* Center Director, Professor [[Sune Toft]] * Center Co-Director, Professor [[Thomas Greve]]<ref name=greve/> * Professor of Astronomy, [[Johan Peter Uldall Fynbo]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.nbi.dk/~jfynbo/|title=Johan Fynbo personal website|date=14 Mar 2020}}</ref> * Professor of Astronomy, [[Georgios Magdis]] (dually employed at the [[Niels Bohr Institute]] and [[Danish Technical University|DTU]])<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.georgiosmagdis.com/|title=Georgios Magdis personal website|date=14 Mar 2020}}</ref> * Associate professor, [[Gabriel Brammer]] * Associate professor, [[Charles Steinhardt]] * Associate professor, [[Darach Watson]] Besides these, DAWN employs a number of [[Affiliate Professor]]s, [[Postdoctoral researcher|Postdocs]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhDs]], as well as the administrative staff.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * '''{{official website|http://dawn.nbi.ku.dk}}''' * [https://www.nbi.ku.dk/ The Niels Bohr Institue] * [https://www.space.dtu.dk/ DTU Space] * [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Cosmic+Dawn+Center%22/ Google Scholar Papers with DAWN affiliation] * [https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/search/fl=identifier%2C%5Bcitations%5D%2Cabstract%2Cauthor%2Cbibcode%2Ccitation_count%2Ccomment%2Cdoi%2Cid%2Ckeyword%2Cpage%2Cproperty%2Cpub%2Cpub_raw%2Cpubdate%2Cpubnote%2Cread_count%2Ctitle%2Cvolume%2Clinks_data%2Cesources%2Cdata%2Ccitation_count_norm%2Cemail%2Cdoctype&q=aff%3A%22cosmic%20dawn%20center%22%20&rows=25&sort=date%20desc%2C%20bibcode%20desc&start=0&p_=0/ NASA/ADS paper database papers with DAWN affiliation]

'''WOH S377''' is a luminous [[red supergiant]] or red hypergiant star. If placed in our [[solar system]], its [[photosphere]] would engulf the orbit of [[Jupiter]], making it one of the largest stars known.<ref>"Luminosities and mass-loss rates of Local Group AGB stars and red supergiants". Astronomy & Astrophysics. 609. arXiv:1711.07803. Bibcode:2018A&A...609A.114G. doi:10.1051/0004-6361/201731089.</ref>
